repnme.cdata!:
Africa - Western Indian Ocean Islands Oil
            Spill Contingency Planning Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Western Indian Ocean
            Islands Oil Spill Contingency Planning Project convey a
            satisfactory project outcome, likely sustainability, with
            substantial institutional development impact, supported by
            satisfactory Bank and Borrower performances. The lessons
            learned include:  (1) The choice of implementing agency and
            of project coordinator is key to the successful
            implementation of a complex project involving several
            countries and partner; (2) Obtaining government commitment
            during project preparation to specific arrangements for
            institutional and financial sustainability, and continuing
            to focus on the issue during implementation, helps to ensure
            that project investments will be sustained after the project
            closes; (3) Building effective partnerships with relevant
            organizations, industry, and governments of non-beneficiary
            countries can help significantly improve project design and
            implementation; (4) Being clear early during project
            preparation on the scope and nature of partners'
            participation can help prevent conflicts later; and (5)
            Pairing weaker countries with stronger ones in a regional
            project can help to quickly build the capacity of the weaker ones.

440982.trustfund:
TF031561-GLOBAL - ENVIRONMENT,TF021424-GEF1: WESTERN INDIAN OCEAN

repnme.cdata!:
Comoros, Madagascar, Mauritius, Seychelles
            - Western Indian Ocean Islands Oil Spill Contingency
            Planning Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Western Indian Ocean Islands Oil
            Spill Contingency Planning Project aims to protect the
            environmental integrity of the coastal and marine ecosystems
            of the western Indian Ocean by helping the islands of
            Comoros, Mauritius, Madagascar, and Seychelles ratify and
            comply with international conventions and protocols that
            require states to develop and maintain adequate capacity to
            respond to oil pollution emergencies. The first of five
            components assists the four countries in upgrading their
            national legislative framework to accede to the relevant
            covenants and protocols by sponsoring a regional workshop on
            convention ratification and implementation; and providing
            expert consultants. The second component helps develop
            national contingency plans by improving environment data
            collection and management systems, identifying and
            establishing priorities, testing national contingency plans,
            and carrying out exercises. The third component evaluates
            local handling facilities, anticipates an accident scenario,
            appraises local and climatic conditions, creates a response
            strategy, identifies equipment, and provides training. The
            fourth component builds national capacity by designing and
            holding expert-led workshops and an expert-developed and
            tested response manual, providing training, and funding
            government participation in international seminars. The
            fifth component develops regional planning and agreements
            for cooperation, training, and coordination.
